They not only serve as a  real-time public bulletin board, but they also as an instant customer service tool.\n\nPlus, the location targeting makes it a much better advertising and communication tool than a plain old website.

Unlearning what the mainstream teaches you often takes more time and effort than it took to learn it.\n\nBecause you not only have to relearn, but you also have to resist the temptation to revert.

@ChrisChattin Huh? I think you missed the point I'm making\n\nWanting to be world class is a great goal. But don't expect yourself to be World class 3 months into the process and then give up because you aren't seeing results

i will likely add to this later

DONT LOVE: Animal mistreatment

There are lots and lots of stray cats and dogs on the streets of Cairo. Some of which look unhealthy and scared.

I have heard that cruelty towards stray animals is common in Egypt (e.g. poisoning stray dogs is a real thing)
LOVE: Weather\n\nWho doesn't love some sun in the middle of the winter? The temperature has been in the high 60s or low 70s. Truly perfect.

DONT LOVE: Unhealthy lifestyle

As good as the food is, many of the dishes are quite unhealthy (fried, breaded, massive portions). The lifestyle also seems somewhat sedentary.

As a result, 62% percent of Egyptian adults are overweight and 31% are obese.

LOVE: Conservative attire

Women here dress conservatively, obviously. Coming from a moderately conservative Indian family, I find it appealing.

Obviously, a stark contrast from the thot lifestyle you find in Los Angeles...

DONT LOVE: Dirty

It is completely normal to see piles of garbage just laying around in the middle of the city. Like, everywhere.

Having lived in India, I am used to it. But for anyone who comes from a clean environment, it may not be very hospitable.

LOVE: People

Despite being an ethnically homogeneous place (99.6% of population is Egyptian), people have been welcoming. 

The service here has also been incredible. People are polite, respectful, and cheerful.

DONT LOVE: Pollution

Cairo is the second most polluted city in the world (New Delhi is #1).

You can feel the bitter taste in your mouth and itchy eyes. Easy to take air quality for granted until you live in a place with really bad air quality.

LOVE: Food

As a meat lover, this place is heaven. The meat is amazingly prepared and part of almost every dish.

Also, I realized that I had not tried hummus or kebab until I tried it in Egypt. On another level.

Also, their bread is SO good. And I don't even like bread...
Things I love and don't love about Cairo so far:\n\n(note: been here for less than a week so take this with a grain of salt)

Creativity is nothing but two familiar ideas colliding to form something new and novel.\n\nWhenever you are stuck creatively, try changing your environment to increase the chances of a collision happening. Too much familiarity hinders the creative process.
For example, when you teach a child something, observe how quickly they can learn that thing. If they learn it really quickly, then they are ‚Äútalented‚Äù at that

Plus, reality is that no one has truly figured it all out yet. We‚Äôre all still figuring it out as we go by playing this game called LIFE. And if anyone tells you otherwise, they‚Äôre lying to themselves and you.

If you simply listen to what others tell you is the right thing to do, you‚Äôll never figure out what you‚Äôre truly GOOD at, what you're truly PASSIONATE about, and most importantly, what makes you truly HAPPY.

By taking many chances, meeting many kinds of people, learning different skills, and most importantly, by failing a LOT.\n\nOnly through experience can you really figure out what the right path for you is.

But this assumes The Libra Association is a non-profit registered in Switzerland. As of now, there is no registered non-profit called The Libra Association.

There's just Libra Network.

This Libra Network seems more centralized in FB's control than it appears on their website.
Originally, the @isTruStory community thought that The Swiss Government ultimately controls The Libra Association, which in turn controls the validators. https://t.co/Qd4eb4hvqx

A new LLC called Libra Networks S.a.r.l was registered in Geneva on May 2, 2019. \n\nFurthermore, Facebook Global Holdings II LLC owns all the shares in this newly incorporated LLC. Thus, a single corporation (i.e. Facebook) owns this network. https://t.co/KampoqW1va

As of now, Facebook does control the validators.\n\nFacebook claims that the Libra Association is a "non-profit" in Switzerland and stated they intend to decentralize ownership. But evidence suggests otherwise. üëá https://t.co/ZVOp1HEcOq

TLDR; @isTruStory is pivoting from truth to debate. Our private Alpha launch has proven that instead of verifying claims, TruStory is becoming a powerful way to debate them.

I hope you'll join me on this mission to make the internet more open-minded, because this is the first step in making the internet more trustworthy.

Stay tuned for Beta launch later this summer. In the meantime, join our waitlist:

https://t.co/Z4AtGUwHyN
We knew we needed to embrace this natural development. Who were we to fight it?\n\nWe're making some big product changes over the coming weeks to embrace our new mission.

Instead of existing to validate claims, @isTruStory was becoming a powerful way to debate them.\n\nIts real value is not in finding the truth; it's in fostering healthy debate and surfacing nuanced Arguments.

Arguments had become a profound opportunity for our users to understand different perspectives. To learn from each other. And sometimes, to even change their minds. ü•∞\n\nOften, each side of an Argument has valid viewpoints. And the truth lies somewhere in between.

But perhaps most surprisingly, the most passionate and devoted @isTruStory users weren't using it to "win" or be right. \n\nThey were enjoying the process of debating claims back and forth more so than seeing an outcome. The outcome was merely a byproduct of the process.
It's been amazing and heartwarming to watch the users we've on-boarded take our Values and Guidelines to heart and debate without yelling at each other. ü§ó\n\nhttps://t.co/Q1WhQSm4Bo

On the other hand, subjective claims required interpretation from different people. It required a back-and-forth dialogue and deep conversation before the most compelling arguments started to emerge. \n\nIn turn, this process led to the surfacing of insightful, nuanced viewpoints.

With objective claims, there is an immediate and timely answer. So there really was no need for multiple perspectives. One or two experts in the community would verify or refute the claim. We would agree on it. Then we'd move on.
Within a few weeks, we began to notice something FASCINATING: \n\nThe most interesting, engaging claims were the more subjective ones, not the objective and verifiable ones. https://t.co/XpmMPFyXBu

The answer to some of these claims is obviously not so black and white, so it felt strange that we would punish people for taking the "wrong" side.\n\nBut we were weeks away from launching private Alpha. And I figured the best way to test our assumptions was to launch.
Or take another example where our top contributor, @paulapivat, digs into whether @ethereum is "centralized" or not:\n\nhttps://t.co/KthVHo8YoU

For example, we decided to take on Tuur Demeester's claims about @ethereum. The result? 

Some people were responding with "Confirmed with CAVEAT" while others answered with "Supporting AND Refuting evidence":

https://t.co/V2S8wSRyVj https://t.co/v13zQ9JdSC
Lots of claims were coming in that didn't have unanimous, crystal-clear answers. The answers fell somewhere in between.
Regardless, our community was doing some serious investigative work on various topics. And it felt like we were getting to the bottom of something big.\n\nBut then something started to feel off.

Over the next 3 months, we rigorously trained our passionate and tight-knit community on how to find and validate claims.

The TruStory app wasn't ready yet, so we decided to replicate its function on Discourse, albeit in a rather mundane and analog way.

https://t.co/OjWtWHuwFa

So I started to build out an A-team to make it happen.\n\nWhile the product was being developed, I wanted to get a head-start on building the community. After all, if we wanted to use the collective knowledge of the crowd, we needed a community which would serve as that crowd.

Unfortunately, at the moment, I decided to go along with it. Why? \n\nBecause it seemed to match the first of many use cases I had considered. But deep down, I too was grappling with what exactly this would look like.
But in today's climate, the truth is much harder to come by than lies, especially in mainstream news. \n\nThe second I said "verify claims," the market thought "crowd-sourced fact-checking of NEWS."

However, the article framed TruStory in a different light from what I envisioned.\n\nMy goal was never to "identity scams before they happen." It was to leverage the collective knowledge of the crowd and ‚Äúskin in the game‚Äù to incentivize people to vote on the validity of claims.

It was probably around this time when many of you heard about TruStory thanks to this TechCrunch article. 

For many of you, this is probably the extent of what you know about TruStory:

https://t.co/NPcvoYcVIh

When I first started TruStory, my original vision was to build a tool we could use to crowd-source the verification of claims people make.¬†\n\nBasically, we wanted to use the collective knowledge of the crowd to verify claims.

Everybody wants "the truth." So here's some blunt honesty: \n\nAttaining the truth is impossible if we're afraid to have a healthy debate about important topics and hear both sides of an argument, rather than silencing everything that doesn't fit a narrative.

Over the past year of building @isTruStory, something has become painfully clear‚Ää. 

The problem with the Internet isn't a lack of truth; it's a lack of willingness to have a healthy debate.

https://t.co/gstdzfaV5a

I'm giving up on the pursuit of truth in favor of something more pragmatic:

Creating a safe space to¬†debate.

Here's why:

Few thoughts:

1) The criticism around Bitcoin/Ethereum development not being "decentralized" enough may not have merit. Perhaps this is a strength and not a weakness. Open to hearing counter-arguments.

2) Does the same 80/20 dynamic hold for closed organizations?

You can see the same 80/20 dynamic at play with open-source projects like Bitcoin and Ethereum. As well as in non-crypto projects like React: 

https://t.co/h6poqdfGTE
https://t.co/UG3MTeuURy
https://t.co/fU99GFKNhp https://t.co/d9j6BENHCG

The paper argues otherwise and claims that:

1) Majority of open-source projects are in fact "hero" projects.
2) The commits from ‚Äúhero developers‚Äù result in far fewer bugs than other developers.

Thus, having "heroes" in projects significantly improves code quality.

Just read a fascinating study on "Why Software Projects need Heroes".

A ‚Äúhero‚Äù project is where 80% of the contributions are made by the 20% of the developers.

It's often thought that these projects should be deprecated b/c they cause bottlenecks in development & communication.
Most people will choose the easy path. Don't be most people.

It‚Äôs not about conquering; it‚Äôs about coming out of the conversation with new insights.

Great debates don‚Äôt divide, they enlighten.

Read the rest of the post here: https://t.co/yWaEvxaekF

Instead, it‚Äôs an opportunity for both sides to think critically about a given topic and formulate a more complete picture on the matter.\n\nIn this sense, a debate is actually about opposing sides working together to show each other a different perspective.

In building TruStory, I‚Äôve discovered that debating is the best way to seek and learn the truth.\n\nContrary to what the internet thinks, the purpose of a debate isn‚Äôt to be deemed right or wrong.

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs fight‚Äù has left no room for ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs explore this idea together.‚Äù

It‚Äôs no wonder most of us don‚Äôt want to ‚Äúdebate‚Äù ‚Äî who wants to be thrown into the ringer & get publicly shamed if others don‚Äôt agree with their opinions?

It shouldn‚Äôt be this way. And it doesn‚Äôt have to be.

As a result, internet debates have become a race to react rather than respond. 

Instead of being opportunities for meaningful discussion, they‚Äôve become word wars to win.

Argumentative attitudes have replaced our willingness to understand different perspectives.

Traditional media promotes clickbait and hot takes. And Twitter just happens to be a place where you can see all this in action in real-time.  \n\nSo, unsurprisingly, when most of us hear the word ‚Äúdebate,‚Äù our minds hear the word ‚Äúfight.‚Äù

On the internet, and especially in the crypto world, there‚Äôs a high priority placed on being open and transparent. Yet, both are plagued with closed-mindedness and toxicity. \n\nSocial networks today incentivize outrage, echo chambers, and fragmented conversation.
The problem with the internet is not lack of truth; it‚Äôs lack of willingness to have a healthy conversation. \n\nBut wait, it gets weirder.

If I asked you to publicly debate me on a topic you‚Äôre an expert in, would you say ‚Äúyes‚Äù?

99% of you would say ‚ÄúNO‚Äù

That's because Internet debates are fights, not debates.

When you participate in a Twitter debate, you‚Äôve already lost. 

But why is this? 

To answer this, let‚Äôs put Twitter aside for a moment and pivot to a topic I‚Äôm obsessed with: Debate.

You honestly have better odds at winning the lottery, going to Mars, or walking on water.\n\nI could actually stop this blog post right here. But that would be an unsatisfying ending to this story, right?

Do you watch Game of Thrones? In one of the earlier seasons, there‚Äôs a great quote:

‚ÄúWhen you play the game of thrones, you win or you die. There is no middle ground.‚Äù

Twitter debates are a lot like Game of Thrones ‚Äî except they‚Äôre even more vicious. And there‚Äôs no way to win.

How do you win a Twitter debate?

Spoiler Alert: You don't.

https://t.co/yWaEvxaekF

But of course, having a leader is seen as "bad" in Crypto. How dare we have a leader? üò±

So what's the solution?

I'm excited to talk through this in-depth tomorrow. See you at 11a PST. üôÇ

Without those, you don't have a community.\n\nCommunities don't form norms by accident. They must be intentionally defined. These usually get defined by leadership. When you go full leader-less before these norms are defined, you end up with a bunch of people who are lost / stuck.

I concluded that the Ethereum community needs to figure out what its shared social & political values are. Without shared social and political norms, we can‚Äôt expect people to magically agree on what needs to be done. Open communities form around shared norms.

but simply to stop and reflect for a few minutes each week as I continue to build something I am deeply passionate about, and as I continue this trek to the final destination.\n\nSign up here. First one goes out next week: https://t.co/3FfpO5mB40

But what about the long bumpy (but incredibly fun) road in between?

That's why I'm launching a newsletter to share my journey.

What I write about in this newsletter, I can't say exactly. The point is not to give this structure and meaning,

I often write these down in my journal, in private. But I'm realizing that's not enough. There are many things I'm learning that I want the world to have access to. Most founders only come out with their glorious stories at the finish line.

Building a company stretches me beyond my imagination. Every day is filled with extreme ambiguity, extreme fear, and extreme joy, somehow all at once. The things I learn and do every day are priceless.

IMO, that is what the newer consensus protocols like Proof-of-Stake (e.g. Tendermint, Capser), Thunderalla, Ouroboros Paxos, Honeybadger, DFINITY, Avalanche, etc. are aiming to do.

If we can figure out other ways to steer a distributed network of nodes to agree on the same value consistently such that the transaction log eventually reaches an irreversible state, then why not try?

But this doesn't mean that we can't design consensus protocols that don't need the physical expenditure of energy to create an immutable ledger. The immutability comes from the fact that the state is irreversible, and not the fact that energy was expended.

It assumes an honest majority to expend computational effort, rather than every single node agreeing on a value. It was simple to understand. It was easily deployable. And WALA, that's why we have Bitcoin.

The brilliance of Nakamoto Consensus was making it probabilistic. Instead of every node agreeing on a value, *f(x)* worked such that all of the nodes agree on the probability of the value being correct.

In traditional consensus, f(x) was defined such that all nodes had to communicate and agree on a value. Too complex. Doesn't scale. Doesn't work in open, permissionless systems where anyone can join the network at any time.
In other words, a set of distributed computers are trying to agree on the output of every transaction in order to maintain a consistent transaction log across every computer in the system.
Transactions ‚Üí f(x) ‚Üí Replicated transaction log (i.e. ‚Äúimmutable ledger‚Äù), where f(x) is the consensus algorithm.

I am not a ‚ÄúPoW-hater‚Äù by ANY means, but I fail to see the logical reasoning here.

If we can create an immutable ledger WITHOUT burning so much energy, why wouldn't we seek it out?

The purpose of PoW is to solve a consensus problem: https://t.co/S2pi6DRuAA
